docs.lead_paragraph: Long-term use of antihypertensive drugs to control high blood pressure is safe and effective, and older patients appear to have a lower rate of adverse reactions than younger ones, a study has found. ''While such drugs may have side effects for a great many people, it is clear you can come up with the right regimen for almost everyone,'' said Dr. J. David Curb, principal author of the study, which appears in the issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association to be published Friday. An estimated 25 million Americans have blood pressure high enough to require medical treatment. The condition is associated with heart disease and stroke, which are among the leading causes of death in the nation.

docs.lead_paragraph: The popular idea that a positive mental attitude helps fight disease is disputed by a new study showing that social and psychological factors do not affect the survival of gravely ill cancer patients. Some psychologists have argued that people who are hopeless and passive in the face of serious illness are more likely to die while those who are fighters have a better chance of surviving. The new study, conducted on people with advanced cases of cancer, concluded that their ways of life, social backgrounds and personalities had no bearing on whether they got better or died. Instead, the biology of the disease determined their fates, according to the study, published in Thursday's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

docs.lead_paragraph: MEDICAL researchers have found an experimental model they have long sought, a laboratory animal that naturally develops a disease resembling rheumatoid arthritis. The animal, an inbred strain of mice that develops the condition in its hind legs, is now being used in the search for the cause, cure or improved treatment of a illness that cripples millions of people. After an extensive series of mouse studies, researchers at the University of Alabama Medical School at Birmingham and the World Health Organization collaborating center in Mainz, West Germany, are reporting results that challenge past scientific dogma about what it is that causes the body to destroy the shock-absorbing cartilage in its joints - the anatomical areas where two or more bones meet - and that can bring on permanent pain, swelling and severe lameness. There is some debate over the new findings, and it may take years before they are fully verified. But the Alabama, West German and other researchers believe the new animal model has already begun to provide valuable insights into the nature of arthritis.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many of the most popular recent theatrical feature films, such as ''The Breakfast Club,'' have championed rebellious teen-agers against abusive or uncomprehending parents. But parents will have their day in ''Toughlove,'' a movie for television about a controversial but popular movement that urges parents to get tough with abusive teen-agers. In ''Toughlove,'' which is being made for ABC-TV and is to be shown in the fall, Lee Remick and Bruce Dern co-star as middle-class parents of a troubled teen-age boy (played by Patric Miller, the son of actor-writer Jason Miller) who becomes unruly and uncontrollable when under the influence of drugs. The parents find a remedy for their problem in the Toughlove movement, a group for parents of rebellious teens. David and Phyllis York, the couple who founded the movement, which has 1,500 chapters around the country, are consultants on the movie.
